name: ANP
summary: Philosophically committed to decentralization (DIDs, JSON-LD, E2E encryption). But Asparouhova's insight applies: decentralization doesn't prevent protocolization — it can make it harder to detect. And ANP's complexity (three-layer architecture) risks the Bartleby problem: too much agency demanded of participants, limiting adoption.

feedbackLoop.note: Decentralized systems inherently have weaker feedback loops — who do you complain to?

edgeCases.note: Three-layer architecture (identity, meta-protocol, application) creates many failure modes.

ambiguity.note: Meta-protocol layer uses AI to negotiate protocols at runtime. Outcomes are non-deterministic by design.

redundancy.note: Competes with A2A, ACP, AITP for the same inter-agent communication space.

nesting.note: Identity → meta-protocol → application layer. Agents negotiate protocols within protocols.

exitCost.note: Early stage. Low adoption means low exit cost — but also low value from participation.

identityPenetration.note: Decentralization-as-identity is already strong in Web3 communities. ANP inherits this.

agencyPreservation.note: High agency by design, but complexity may exceed what most participants can manage — the Bartleby trap.

controlInvisibility.note: Decentralized protocols are the hardest to see — 'no one runs it' means no one is accountable.

crisisMindset.note: 'We need decentralization before the corporates take over' — fear-driven narrative.
